headline.main: AIDES ASSERT HART SEEKS TO MINIMIZE DISCORD IN PARTY

results.snippet: After a roller-coaster primary campaign, Senator Gary Hart today determinedly pursued plans for winning the Democratic Presidential nomination.     But his aides stressed his equal determination to emphasize issues and minimize any discord with...

byline.original: By FAY. S. JOYCE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: After a roller-coaster primary campaign, Senator Gary Hart today determinedly pursued plans for winning the Democratic Presidential nomination. But his aides stressed his equal determination to emphasize issues and minimize any discord with Walter F. Mondale. ''He recognizes it's a long shot and will not do anything to hurt the party,'' said his adviser, Patrick H. Caddell. ''But there are other reasons to stay. He represents a large constituency and there are issues and processes that are important to him.''

results.snippet: Fernando Bujones will dance ''Swan Lake'' tonight with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. There is nothing unusual about that. Mr. Bujones, a leading dancer with the company, has danced Prince Siegfried - a signature role...
results.lead_paragraph: Fernando Bujones will dance ''Swan Lake'' tonight with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. There is nothing unusual about that. Mr. Bujones, a leading dancer with the company, has danced Prince Siegfried - a signature role - in the ballet, and with companies around the world, countless times before. But tonight's performance is the final and culminating event of his 10th-anniversary season as a principal dancer with Ballet Theater, a season that finds him touted as the greatest classical dancer of his generation. It is also a season that Mr. Bujones feels has been one of his happiest and most successful in the company.

headline.main: ADD 16 YEARS TO '2001' AND THE RESULT IS '2010'

results.snippet: HOLLYWOOD   ''How do you continue a classic?'' asks Peter Hyams.  The answer, says Mr.  Hyams, who is currently directing ''2010,'' a sequel to ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' is: with a great deal of anxiety and awe.   It was in the spring of 1968 that...
results.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD ''How do you continue a classic?'' asks Peter Hyams. The answer, says Mr. Hyams, who is currently directing ''2010,'' a sequel to ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' is: with a great deal of anxiety and awe. It was in the spring of 1968 that ''2001,'' Stanley Kubrick's half-satiric, half-reverent vision of the bland and depersonalized future of the human race was thrust at movie audiences accustomed to science-fiction movies containing gigantic bugs, decaying monsters or malevolent aliens. Though Mr. Kubrick and Arthur C. Clarke, the respected science-fiction author, who had co-written the screenplay, had envisioned a cinematic parallel to Homer's ''Odyssey,'' and though critics were divided in their opinions, there was no mistaking the reaction of audiences. Despite its mystical ending and deliberate tedious stretches designed to demonstrate the boredom of space flight, ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' was the fifth most successful box-office attraction in a year dominated by ''The Graduate.'' Since then, it has been reissued twice and earned M-G- M a total of more than $24 million in North American theaters.

results.snippet: Jane Gross is a sports reporter for The Times.     THE DARK GLASSES GO on as soon as Carl Lewis leaves the track, and a look of wariness replaces the easy joy that lights his face when he is running or jumping. He stares straight ahead, as hordes...
results.lead_paragraph: Jane Gross is a sports reporter for The Times. THE DARK GLASSES GO on as soon as Carl Lewis leaves the track, and a look of wariness replaces the easy joy that lights his face when he is running or jumping. He stares straight ahead, as hordes of reporters push and shove, and autograph seekers tug at his clothing with a frenzy usually reserved for rock stars. Carl Lewis is, at this moment, America's most dazzling athlete. Since he began dominating the world of track and field about four years ago, he has become a magnet for publicity, curiosity and criticism. And now, with the Olympics just a little more than a month off, and the track and field trials underway this weekend in Los Angeles, the heat around this self- contained 22-year-old is more intense than ever.

results.snippet: A Chinese astronaut will definitely participate in a forthcoming United States space shuttle mission, officials say, although negotiations were not completed in time for a joint announcement on President Reagan's visit to China a month ago.    ...

byline.original: By Phil Gailey and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: A Chinese astronaut will definitely participate in a forthcoming United States space shuttle mission, officials say, although negotiations were not completed in time for a joint announcement on President Reagan's visit to China a month ago. Western diplomatic sources in Peking assured a visiting Washingtonian recently that planning for this demonstration of international amity in space was on schedule and official confirmation could be expected in a few months. The flight itself will probably not take place until later this decade. The Chinese have sent up more than half a dozen satellites since their first successful launching in 1970. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have invited Brazil, France and West Germany to assign astronauts to go on missions with American teams. China would be the first Communist nation to send along an astronaut.

results.lead_paragraph: Monday President Reagan greets President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka in a South Lawn ceremony and later holds a state dinner in his honor. Burger addresses a conference on ''Factories With Fences: The Prison Industries Approach to Correctional Dilemmas.'' 9:45 A.M., Lisner Auditorium.

headline.main: SHUTTLE EXPERIMENTS SHOW HOW ZERO GRAVITY AFFECTS GASES

results.snippet: IT was a simple experiment, as simple as a    light bulb. On a space shuttle mission last   February cameras took time-lapse photographs of the glowing gases in ordinary commercial arc lamps to observe the behavior of the gases in the absence of...
results.lead_paragraph: IT was a simple experiment, as simple as a light bulb. On a space shuttle mission last February cameras took time-lapse photographs of the glowing gases in ordinary commercial arc lamps to observe the behavior of the gases in the absence of gravity. Predictably the gases behaved differently in space, without the disturbances of gravitational convection forces, than they did in comparable light bulbs photographed on the earth. The orbiting lights burned brighter and more efficiently, according to researchers at the GTE Corporation, which developed and analyzed the experiment.

headline.main: NASA Picks 3 Astronomers To Train for Shuttle Flights

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named three astronomers to train for 1986 and 1987 space shuttle missions devoted to studying stars and galaxies with an array of delicate instruments, including cameras to look at Halley's...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named three astronomers to train for 1986 and 1987 space shuttle missions devoted to studying stars and galaxies with an array of delicate instruments, including cameras to look at Halley's Comet.

results.snippet: WILD BERRIES. By Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 296 pages. Morrow. $15.95.  Wild Berries,'' Yevgeny Yevtushenko's first novel, is the Soviet equivalent of a potboiler. It consists of action, sex, landscape and elementary...
results.lead_paragraph: WILD BERRIES. By Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. 296 pages. Morrow. $15.95. Wild Berries,'' Yevgeny Yevtushenko's first novel, is the Soviet equivalent of a potboiler. It consists of action, sex, landscape and elementary discussions of Russian life and literature. The descriptions of landscape are the best part; Mr. Yevtushenko is, after all, a well-known poet. Here and there, he manages a nice vignette or two, but generally the writing and the plotting are slapdash. In fact, it's remarkable that such an experienced poet should be so clumsy even in his first novel. It's hard to say whether he's careless or disorganized or whether he's attempting to borrow the loose, associational structure of modern Western fiction. Whatever the case may be, it doesn't work. In one chapter, the book leaps from Siberia to Chile to show President Salvador Allende Gossens having his portrait painted. The sole link here seems to be that there are politics everywhere. Another chapter introduces a California rock group called the Tails, and here the cross-reference is the fact that a member of the group had visited the Soviet Union as a high school student.

headline.main: 10 PEOPLE HONORED FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO PUBLIC SERVICES

results.snippet: An orphan from Nampa, Idaho, who made a promise to ''help the children who fall through the cracks,'' was among 10 people honored at the Supreme Court today by the American Institute for Public Service.    At the annual Jefferson Awards ceremony,...
results.lead_paragraph: An orphan from Nampa, Idaho, who made a promise to ''help the children who fall through the cracks,'' was among 10 people honored at the Supreme Court today by the American Institute for Public Service. At the annual Jefferson Awards ceremony, Donna Velnick was honored for running Hope House, a home for orphaned and neglected children. ''I just made a promise to myself to help the children who fall through the cracks,'' she told an audience of 100 people in the Court's East Conference Room.

results.snippet: IN recent years, most of the chemical industry has been playing follow the leader. Du Pont, the nation's largest chemical manufacturer, bought the Conoco oil company. Dow Chemical, No. 2 in the business, acquired a pharmaceutical operation. And...
results.lead_paragraph: IN recent years, most of the chemical industry has been playing follow the leader. Du Pont, the nation's largest chemical manufacturer, bought the Conoco oil company. Dow Chemical, No. 2 in the business, acquired a pharmaceutical operation. And many other chemical companies are also responding to the huge worldwide overcapacity in basic chemicals by diversifying. But the Celanese Corporation has marched to a different drummer, keeping a stubborn commitment to its core businesses. So far, its nonconformist strategy is paying off. After being the only major chemical company to lose money in 1982, Celanese will likely outperform the industry this year, and report record profits. But it is too soon for the company to rest on its laurels: Because the chemical industry is so cyclical, Celanese's failure to diversify could leave it especially vulnerable to the next downswing.

results.snippet: The voices of the astronauts and engineers in the launching control center at the Kennedy Space Center were calm and businesslike today throughout the attempt to launch the space shuttle Discovery.   The astronauts spent most of the emergency...
results.lead_paragraph: The voices of the astronauts and engineers in the launching control center at the Kennedy Space Center were calm and businesslike today throughout the attempt to launch the space shuttle Discovery. The astronauts spent most of the emergency period listening to a jumble of voices as instructions and reports went back and forth between experts in the launching control room.

results.snippet: Sure, your apartment is small, but why take it out on the cat?    Richard Glavin explains that he is going a little crazy. Like so many other New Yorkers, he tells of once living in a nice, normal apartment designed for human habitation before...
results.lead_paragraph: Sure, your apartment is small, but why take it out on the cat? Richard Glavin explains that he is going a little crazy. Like so many other New Yorkers, he tells of once living in a nice, normal apartment designed for human habitation before moving to Manhattan and a typical apartment with the bedroom, home office, dining room and living room all squished into one. His separate 2-by-3-foot kitchen is the envy of many friends.
